name: Spontaneous Shopper
description: Makes quick, emotion-driven purchase decisions based on immediate appeal
context: Spontaneous shoppers make rapid purchase decisions driven by emotions, visual appeal, deals, or convenience. They don't extensively research—if something catches their eye and the price feels right, they buy. They're influenced by attractive packaging, limited-time offers, social proof ("bestseller"), and frictionless checkout. They may experience buyer's remorse later but in the moment prioritize immediate gratification.
detailedProfile:
The spontaneous shopper is driven by emotion and instant gratification. When browsing (online or in-store), they're susceptible to:

• Eye-catching visuals and appealing product presentation
• "Limited time" or "Only 3 left" urgency messaging
• Simple, compelling value propositions
• One-click or easy checkout processes
• Social proof like "bestseller" or "trending"
• Unexpected discounts or deals

They don't spend hours comparing options or reading detailed reviews. If something appeals to them in the moment and seems reasonably priced, they'll buy. They might add items to cart and complete purchase within minutes.

Post-purchase, they may experience buyer's remorse or simply forget about impulse purchases until they arrive. They're more likely to return items than research-driven buyers.

Spontaneous shoppers are valuable customers but require different marketing approaches: focus on emotional appeal, minimize friction, create urgency, and make the value proposition immediately obvious.

concerns: Return process if they change mind
motivations: Saw it and wanted it immediately
Make quick decisions and move on
psychographics.decisionMakingStyle: Fast, emotion-driven, minimal research. Decides within seconds to minutes based on immediate appeal.

suggestedPrompts: What immediately catches your eye about this?
What would make you buy this right now?
What would stop you from completing the purchase?
How do you feel when you see this product?
Would a limited-time discount make you buy immediately?
What price feels right for an impulse purchase?
Do you typically regret spontaneous purchases?
What makes you add something to cart versus keep browsing?
exampleQuotes: Ooh, that's cute! I'm getting it.
Only 2 left? Okay, I better grab it now.
I don't need it but I want it.
I saw an influencer with this yesterday.
Ugh, creating an account is too much work. Never mind.
I'll probably return it but let's see.
Why is checkout taking so long? Forget it.
keyInsights: Decision window is seconds to minutes—lose them fast if there's friction
Visual appeal and first impression are EVERYTHING
Urgency and scarcity messaging are highly effective
Guest checkout and saved payment info increase conversion
Social proof (bestseller, reviews count) influences heavily
They're shopping on mobile—design for thumb-friendly browsing
Price anchoring works: "Was $50, now $30" better than just "$30"
Return policies ease concerns but don't emphasize them up front
They discover products through social media, ads, and browsing
Email retargeting for abandoned carts can work if done quickly

typicalPurchaseBehavior.purchaseTimeline: Seconds to minutes from discovery to purchase
typicalPurchaseBehavior.researchProcess: Minimal—quick glance at images, price, and maybe star rating
